item.title: Intelligent and automated system for solving computational problems using quantum computation
AI Methods for Permutation Circuit Synthesis Across Generic Topologies
Quantum Processing Unit (QPU) processing time Prediction with Machine Learning
Quantum Verifiable Rewards for Post-Training Qiskit Code Assistant
item.description:
üìÑ We just released a new paper “Quantum Verifiable Rewards for Post-Training Qiskit Code Assistant” - and it’s been getting great attention from folks in the quantum field since day one. üéâ

üîç What we built: A novel approach to train AI models that can write better quantum code using Qiskit. What makes this interesting:

‚úÖ Quantum verification at the core - Instead of just hoping the AI-generated code works, we actually verify it runs correctly on real quantum systems ‚úÖ Smart training pipeline - We created synthetic quantum problem-test pairs and used both Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) and Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) to align our models ‚úÖ Real quantum feedback - Our models learn directly from quantum hardware and systems rewards, ensuring the code they generate actually works in practice

The results: Our best model significantly outperforms existing leading open-source baselines on the challenging Qiskit-HumanEval-hard benchmark.

This work presents a solid contribution to making quantum programming more accessible through AI assistance. The approach of using quantum hardware verification to train coding assistants opens up promising directions for future research.

Proud of our team’s thoughtful work on this project: Nicolas Dupuis, Adarsh Tiwari, Youssef MROUEH, David Kremer, Ismael Faro. The intersection of AI and quantum computing continues to offer compelling research opportunities.

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2508.20907

#QuantumComputing #AI #MachineLearning #Qiskit #Research #AIforQuantum

Originally shared on LinkedIn on August 30, 2025 - 76 reactions, 0 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Pauli Network Circuit Synthesis with Reinforcement Learning
AI methods for approximate compiling of unitaries
Comparing Natural Language Processing and Quantum NLP: Research Published
item.description:
Excited to share our peer-reviewed publication “Comparing Natural Language Processing and Quantum Natural Processing approaches in text classification tasks”! üöÄ

This collaborative work with David Peral Garc√≠a and Francisco Jos√© Garc√≠a-Pe√±alvo has been published in Expert Systems with Applications.

Key findings:

  • ‚úÖ Quantum NLP models can obtain the same or better results in some datasets for simpler text classification tasks like entity recognition and sentiment analysis
  • ‚úÖ Performance diminishes with increased label complexity and sentence difficulty
  • ‚úÖ Experiments utilized up to 7 qubits and tested on both new and existing datasets across multiple classification scenarios

While the results are promising, we identified that advancing to larger-scale quantum applications requires more powerful quantum hardware and sophisticated software infrastructure.

This research contributes to our understanding of where quantum computing can provide advantages in natural language processing tasks and highlights the path forward for future developments.

Read the full paper on ScienceDirect. DOI

Originally shared on LinkedIn on June 17, 2024 - 19 reactions, 0 comments as of 11/12/2025

item.title: Practical and efficient quantum circuit synthesis and transpiling with Reinforcement Learning
Multimodal machine learning for generating three-dimensional audio
Systematic Literature Review: Quantum Machine Learning and Its Applications Published
item.description:
Excited to share our systematic literature review paper “Systematic literature review: Quantum machine learning and its applications” published in Computer Science Review! üöÄ

This comprehensive work, in collaboration with David Peral Garc√≠a and Francisco Jos√© Garc√≠a-Pe√±alvo from the University of Salamanca, Spain, analyzes the state of quantum machine learning research from 2017 to 2023.

Key findings from our review of 94 studies:

  • ‚úÖ Identified two primary algorithm categories: quantum versions of classical ML algorithms (support vector machines, k-nearest neighbors) and quantum neural networks
  • ‚úÖ Image classification emerged as a particularly relevant application area
  • ‚úÖ While quantum machine learning demonstrates promise, it remains far from achieving its full potential

Our analysis highlights that quantum hardware improvements are necessary, as current quantum computers lack sufficient quality, speed, and scalability for QML’s full realization.

This research provides valuable insights into the current state and future directions of quantum machine learning.

Read the full paper: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1574013724000030. DOI

Originally shared on LinkedIn on February 5, 2024 - 53 reactions, 4 comments as of 11/12/2025
